newsitem.title: PERU: Peru remembers hostage crisis victims one month on.
newsitem.headline: Peru remembers hostage crisis victims one month on.

text.p: Peruvians marked the one month anniversary on Thursday of the bloody end to a 126-day hostage crisis at the Japanese ambassador's home with church services, remembering the 17 victims of the military's rescue strike.
The two Peruvian commandos and a captive local judge, who all died in the lightning assault, were honoured with official ceremonies and Roman Catholic Masses.
Relatives of some of the 14 slain Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) rebels visited their poor graves in Lima shantytowns.

The street on which the remains of Col. Juan Valer are housed was renamed after the commando, officially honoured as a national hero since he died April 22 rescuing Peru's key hostage, Foreign Minister Francisco Tudela.
Most of the dead rebels' families do not know where the security forces buried them.

Despite the vigilance of intelligence service agents, the sister of the hostage-takers' second-in-command, Rolly Rojas, Adilia, visited her brother's humble grave -- an above-ground niche near the prison where the rebel was once jailed.
"Even though they have wiped out his soul, he is still with us," Adilia Rojas said.
The national radio station CPN also marked the month anniversary by repeating the gentle Japanese "taisa" music, which became a feature of the crisis.
Each day, the music -- normally played at Japanese factories to help workers exercise -- was dedicated to the 72 hostages, including a score of Tokyo diplomats and businessmen.

And in a reminder of the frequent demonstrations during the siege that called for a bloodless solution, children in several Lima suburbs marched carrying white balloons and placards which read "Long live peace!."
